LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY

Two loans from the Asian Development Bank (ADB), consisting of
(i) a policy loan and (ii) an investment loan in support of the Social
Security  Sector  Development  Program  (SSSDP).  A  technical
assistance (TA) grant will be provided on approval of the SSSDP.

From  1921  to  1990  Mongolia  achieved  high  levels  of  human
development with no recorded poverty. Since 1990 poverty levels
have risen to over 35 percent, with real unemployment estimated
at  over  17  percent.  Among  the  most  adversely  affected  are  the
elderly, disabled, children, and single parent families. Government
policy  for  poverty  reduction  is  to  (i)  reduce  unemployment,  (ii)
provide  essential  social  welfare  services  for  the  most  vulnerable
who  are  incapable  of  working,  and  (iii)  provide  social  insurance
services  to  support  working  people  at  risk  of  falling  into  poverty.
Civil  society  has  also  become  active  in  addressing  poverty
through providing informal social security services.

However,  much  of  the  formal  social  security  system  has  shown
itself  to  be  increasingly  ineffective.  In  particular,  its  emphasis  on
universal  coverage  has  proven  unsustainable  given  severe
budgetary  constraints.  Average  disbursements  to  more  than  the
over 228,000 beneficiaries of the Social Assistance Fund in 2000
amounted to just $3.82 equivalent per person per month. There is,
therefore,  an  urgent  need  to  focus  public  resources  more  on  the
poorest to allow for increased levels of assistance per beneficiary.
In  addition,  the  Government  needs  to  mobilize  communities  and
to work with the private sector to increase resources and improve
efficiency  of  social  services  provided  to  the  most  vulnerable.
Combating  unemployment  is  hindered  by  the  low  coverage  of
employment  services,  including  retraining  and  job  counseling,
which reach only a small proportion of the unemployed. The ability
of  social  insurance  systems  to  prevent  people  from  falling  into
poverty  has  also  been  curtailed  by  the  falling  number  of  people
contributing  to  the  schemes  and  employers’  low  levels  of
compliance with compulsory contributions. Arrears of public sector
agency social insurance payments exceed $3.1 million equivalent.

Reform is, therefore, necessary to ensure that the social security
system  can  serve  Mongolia’s  needs.  Top  priorities  must  be  the
maintenance  and  improvement  of  social  welfare  services  for  the
most  vulnerable:  the  elderly,  disabled,  and  children,  and  single-
parent  families.  At  the  same  time,  the  system  needs  to  help  the
unemployed  and  underemployed 
find  productive  and

    Objectives and Scope

The  sector  goals  are  to  reduce  poverty  and  increase  security
among  vulnerable  groups  by 
increasing  employment  and
providing essential social security services for those incapable of
working.  The  specific  purpose  of  the  SSSDP  is  fully  compatible
with  the  sector  goals  and  aims  to  strengthen  the  social  security
system’s  ability  to  deliver  essential  welfare,  insurance,  and
employment services to the ultra poor, very poor, and those close
to the poverty line.

As a core poverty intervention, the SSSDP will include both direct and
indirect poverty interventions. Policy reforms to social welfare services
and  benefits,  employment  services,  and  social  insurance  systems
(unemployment  and  occupational  injury  and  disease  insurance),  will
directly benefit up to 820,000 people, of whom 72 percent live below
the  poverty  line.  Primary  beneficiary  groups  are  people  with
disabilities,  the  elderly,  female-headed  households,  the  unemployed,
and  children  in  difficult  circumstances.  The  SSSDP  will  contribute  to
human development by providing employment-oriented education and
training  for  the  unemployed  and  vulnerable groups,  including  people
with disabilities. The SSSDP will also improve the quality of life for the
poor  who  depend  on  social  welfare  services  by  improving  existing
services  and  developing  community-based  social  welfare  services
more sensitive to local needs and demands.

The  investment  project  will  directly  assist  2,500  poor,  especially
people  with  disabilities  and  the  elderly  in  difficult  circumstances,  by
upgrading nursing services and the National Center for Rehabilitation
of  the  Disabled.  In  addition,  three  pilot  social  security  centers  will
improve service provision to more than 5,000 poor clients. Targeting
the  extremely  poor,  the  investment  project  will  initiate  community-
based  projects  supporting  4,000  people.  The  investment  project  will
also aim to promote employment of the poor by educating and training
14,000  unemployed  people  and  developing  essential  employment

INTRODUCTION

2.

investment priorities with the Government.

Macroeconomic Context

7.
Since  the  beginning  of  the  transition  in  1990,  Mongolia  has  made  great  progress  in
developing a democratic form of government and a market-based economic system. During the
first  four  years  of  adjustment,  the  economy  contracted  sharply  due  to  the  withdrawal  of
assistance  from  the  former  Soviet  Union,  equivalent  to  about  30  percent  of  gross  domestic
product (GDP), and the break up of the trading system with the member countries of the Council
for  Mutual  Economic  Assistance.  The  collapse  of  the  state  budget  led  to  drastic  cuts  in
subsidies  and  welfare  programs.  Furthermore,  economic  restructuring  and  the  privatization
process led to a severe retrenchment in public sector employment, and to the closure of many
nonviable  enterprises.  Although  much  of  the  labor  force  shed  was  absorbed  by  the  extensive
livestock  sector,  and  by  the  growing  informal  economy,  unemployment  and  poverty  increased
rapidly.

8.
From 1994 to 1999 the economy recovered, with real GDP growth averaging 3.6 percent
annually.  The  source  of  growth  was  primarily  a  private-sector-led  recovery  in  agriculture
following  the  privatization  of  livestock,  manufacturing,  and  services.  In  1996  the  Government
adopted  an  ambitious  reform  program  to  complete  the  transition  to  a  market  economy,
accelerate growth, and reduce poverty. Key elements of the program included reducing inflation,
liberalizing prices, streamlining the public sector, developing the private sector, and establishing
a restructured social security system. As a result, private sector activity increased sharply and
exports grew as terms of trade improved in 1997. The exchange rate stabilized and inflation fell
from  47  percent  in  1996  to  20  percent  in  1997.  In  1997  Mongolia  joined  the  World  Trade
Organization and most import taxes were abolished.

9.

and the Russian Federation. Lower tax revenues and undermining bank loan portfolios and thus

The  fiscal  deficit  widened  to  12  percent  of  GDP,  from  9  percent  in  1997,  and  the  togrog

12.
Major  achievements  in  macroeconomic  management  during  the  second  half  of  the
1990s  include  the  control  of  inflation  and  continued  growth;  however,  short  to  medium  term
economic  prospects  are  uncertain.  The  dependence  of  the  economy  on  the  export  of  a  few
primary  commodities,  such  as  copper,  gold,  and  cashmere,  makes  the  country  vulnerable  to
external shocks and contributes to the weakness of the external account. The extremely harsh
winters  of  1999-2000  and  2000-2001  have  resulted  in  the  loss  of  close  to  20  percent  of
Mongolia’s livestock, which may have far reaching implications for growth and poverty reduction
in  the  coming  years.  Tax  revenue  collection  needs  to  be  improved  to  strengthen  the  fiscal
position and direct foreign investment should be encouraged. The banking system continues to
be  relatively  weak,  and  the  range  of  available  financial  services  narrow,  thereby  constraining
private sector development and employment growth.

2. 

Social Context

13.
Under the command economy before 1990, the social sectors in Mongolia received high
levels  of  investment  and  fiscal  support.  Access  to  employment  was  nearly  universally
guaranteed  and  there  was  no  recognized  unemployment.  Health  and  education  services  were
widespread  and  accessible  because  of  the  high  priority  the  Government  placed  on  human
development. The social security system was based on a combination of consumer subsidies,
universal  benefits  supported  by  the  central  budget,  and  state  sector  wages.  All  sectors  of
society  were  covered  by  the  pension  system  and  the  state  also  provided  a  comprehensive
range of social protection benefits to families, children, and groups designated as “vulnerable.”
About 40 percent of Government expenditures were devoted to social development.6

14.
Following  transition,  the  Government  made  steps  to  change  the  social  welfare  system
from  provision  of  universal  access  to  targeted  interventions.  Expenditures  on  social  security

efforts,  the  social  welfare  system,  which  covers  retirement,  disability  and  survivor  pensions,
work  injury,  unemployment,  maternity  benefits,  health,  social  insurance  system,  and  the
National Poverty Alleviation Program (NPAP) has had limited success in reducing poverty.

Employment Services and Worker Safety

30.
The  Central  Employment  Regulation  Office  (CERO)  is  the  primary  agency  responsible
for providing employment services to the unemployed. These include information and advisory
services as well as support for direct job placement (e.g., through public works) or organization

117 staff throughout the country in 29 employment regulation offices (EROs).

31.
The EROs are the primary point of contact for the unemployed in their search for jobs.
However,  availability  of  services  is  restricted  to  only  a  small  proportion  of  the  de  facto

comprise  the  majority  of  the  population  looking  for  work,  and  people  working  in  the  informal
sector.  Consequently  in  2000  only  8,842  people,  23  percent  of  the  formally  unemployed  were
eligible to receive employment services. However, as most unemployment is unrecorded, fewer
than 8 percent of the de facto unemployed are likely to be able to avail of employment services.

C. 

Constraints and Issues

1. 

Social Welfare Services

37.
Mongolia currently is attempting to maintain a complex and very extensive social welfare
network  on  minimal  resources.17  With  few  resources  available  in  the  SAF,  benefits  are
completely  inadequate  to  lift  beneficiaries  out  of  poverty.  In  2000  228,014  SAF  beneficiaries
received  an  average  of  just  $3.82  equivalent  per  month.  In  addition,  well  over  650,000  poor
people are unable to avail of even this support under the SAF. This is compounded by the fact
that a large number of SAF beneficiaries are not poor, as benefits are provided on a universal
basis.  With  little  prospect  of  increased  budgetary  support,  existing  resources  should  be  better
focused on the ultra poor and very poor who are not capable of working.

38.
Effective planning and targeting of scarce resources is, however, difficult given the lack
of comprehensive data available to policy makers and planners. Although excellent information
on poverty exists at the district level, the processing of such information up to the central level is
weak, which makes it difficult for planners to respond adequately to shifting patterns of demand
for social welfare services. Improved information systems are needed.

39. With  regard  to  in-kind  services  (including  nursing  homes),  Mongolia’s  reliance  on
centralized  institutions  for  the  elderly  and  disabled  is  costly,  and  limits  coverage  of  services,
excluding  many  in  need.  While  institutionalization  may  be  required  for  a  limited  number  of
people,  a  complementary  system  needs  to  be  developed  to  expand  service  coverage.  The
Government  prefers  a  community-based  approach  whereby  services  are  developed  and
provided  at  the  community  level.  In  Mongolia  this  can  typically  be  done  at  the  district  level.
Although  such  approaches  have  been  implemented  in  Mongolia  in  a  limited  manner,  they  are
still  relatively  new.  They  do,  however,  offer  substantial  scope  for  mobilizing  vitally  needed
resources at the community level for the provision of social welfare services to the vulnerable in
their own communities.

IV.

THE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM

A. 

Rationale

70.
From  1921  to  1990,  Mongolia  achieved  substantial  progress  in  human  development.
These  gains  are,  however,  being  rapidly  eroded,  largely  through  declines  in  quality  and
coverage of social security and other social services, and poverty levels have risen sharply. The
Government  has  responded  though  interventions  such  as  the  NPAP  as  well  as  commencing
major  reforms  in  the  social  sector.  Civil  society  has  responded  well  to  the  challenges  as
witnessed  by  the  rapid  development  of  NGOs  providing  informal  social  security  services.  The
new Government has also adopted an action plan that sets reducing unemployment as the main
pillar of its bid to reduce poverty, while providing social welfare services to the most vulnerable
and social insurance services to prevent people from falling into poverty.

71.
However, much of the formal social security system has shown itself to be increasingly
ineffective  in  Mongolia’s  move  to  a  market-oriented  economy.  In  particular,  its  emphasis  on
cash  transfers  to  a  large  number  of  beneficiaries  has  proven  unsustainable  under  the  severe
budgetary  constraints  faced  by  the  Government.  In  addition,  employment  promotion  services
and unemployment insurance systems reach only a small proportion of the de facto unemployed
and even when they do so, are largely ineffective. Reform is, therefore, necessary.

Top priorities must be the maintenance and improvement of social welfare services for
72.
the most vulnerable groups of society to help them out of poverty and to ensure all their basic
needs are met. These groups are most affected by poverty. At the same time, the system needs
to support the unemployed and underemployed to find productive, viable, and sustainable jobs.

73.
External  support  is  required  for  restructuring  the  social  security  system  given  the
Government’s  financial  and  technical  capacity  constraints,  including  lack  of  experience  in
market-based  systems.  This  process  will  require  investments  at  both  policy  and  investment
levels  for  social  welfare,  employment  promotion,  social  insurance,  and  better  sector  planning.
Loans will need to be directed at establishing effective and sustainable social security systems
in line with the development requirements of modern Mongolia.

the  beneficiaries.  The  primary  strategic  development  objective  is  poverty  reduction  and  the

1.  Environmental Analysis

No  adverse  environmental  effects  are  expected  from  the  SSSDP.  Civil  works  will  be

92.

2.  Social Analysis

93.
The social analysis  (Appendix 10) indicates that the SSSDP will improve the quality and
coverage  of  social  assistance  benefits  and  welfare  services,  employment  services,  and  social
insurance for poor people, including vulnerable groups (para.18) in particular. The SSSDP will
increase  the  proportion  of  poor  and  vulnerable  groups  that  are  covered  and  the  amount  they
receive through improved means testing.

94.
The  current  system  of  welfare  services  for  the  elderly,  PWD,  and  children  in  difficult
circumstances is highly centralized and institution based. The SSSDP will focus on development
of community-based approaches to providing welfare services, to enable those requiring social
services  to  remain  close  to  their  communities.  A  community-based  approach  has  proved  very
effective  in  targeting  the  intended  beneficiaries.  In  economic  terms,  a  community-based
approach provides benefits, delivery costs will be reduced, and income generation opportunities
for the local economy will increase. A community-based approach is based on an understanding
of  peoples’  vulnerability  and  needs,  and  of  their  assets  and  capabilities.  Different  groups  in
different  localities,  will  require  varied  types  of  interventions.  To  support  a  community-based
approach,  a  new  framework  for  social  services  is  required  to  define  the  institutions,  assign
responsibilities, and ensure proper training of social workers to adapt to the new system.

95.
One  of  the  main  factors  contributing  to  the  high  poverty  level  in  Mongolia  is  lack  of
employment  opportunities.  Vocational  and  skills  training  is  required  to  upgrade  the  skills  of  a
labor  force  that  has  been  trained  to  meet  the  job  requirements  of  a  command  economy.
Vocational and skills training is also essential for the many young people who need to enter the
labor  market  for  the  first  time.  There  is  a  marked  rural-urban  disparity  in  access  to  training
opportunities. By decentralizing vocational and skills training as suggested in the SSSDP, rural
unemployed will have increased access to improve their skills and employment opportunities.

96.
The social analysis indicates that Mongolia has a large number of PWD who are capable
of working. Mainstreaming PWD in vocational and skills training will provide these groups with
income  opportunities,  lift  a  significant  number  of  PWD  out  of  poverty,  and  integrate  some
excluded groups in the mainstream of the economy.

Social  insurance  systems  have  been  recognized  as  important  because  they  provide  a

their social insurance (pensions), and all recipients of social insurance would be poor if they did

the employed are covered by social insurance on a compulsory basis. However, only 22 percent
of herders and the self-employed are covered on a voluntary basis. Thus, most of these groups
are vulnerable to loss of income due to illness, disability, work injury, and old age.

Unemployment  benefits  from  the  social  insurance  system  only  cover  3  percent  of  the

A. 

Expected Impacts

1. 

Benefits

129.
The  main  benefit  of  the  SSSDP  will  be  to  reduce  poverty  and  increase  security  of
vulnerable  groups  by  creating  a  sustainable  social  security  system  that  is  (i)  capable  of
delivering  adequate  essential  services  to  the  poor,  and  (ii)  cost  effective  and  efficient.  The
project  will  improve  quality  and  coverage  of  social  assistance  benefits  and  welfare  services,
employment  services,  and  social  insurance,  which  will  directly  benefit  poor  and  vulnerable
groups  dependent  on  social  services.  Principal  beneficiaries  of  the  reformed  social  security
system  will  include  870,000  people,  72  percent  living  below  the  poverty  line.  The  direct
beneficiaries of the investment components of the project are 20,000 very poor, including most
vulnerable children, elderly and PWD: all groups that have disproportionately borne the brunt of
the difficult transition period.

130. Developing  management  information  systems  in  social  welfare  agencies  and  EROs  at
provincial  and  district  levels,  will  contribute  to  more  effectively  monitoring  mechanisms  of  the
impact  of  different  social  welfare  and  employment  services,  and  thus  allow  for  more  effective
and equitable use of social welfare resources and improved employment conditions.

131.
The  focus  on  fostering  private  sector  participation  in  providing  social  security  services
over the medium to long term is expected to mobilize resources to supplement public budgetary
expenditure and provide users with a greater choice of services. Improved targeting will mean a
more  efficient  use  of  resources  and  institutional  and  organizational  reforms  will  result  in
significant recurrent cost savings.

The development of a comprehensive master plan will benefit the social security sector
132.
by providing a formal framework for medium- and long-term policy and planning. This will permit
a  shift  from  short-term,  uncoordinated  interventions  to  a  more  effective  system  better  able  to
address poverty reduction on a sustainable basis.

2. 

Impact on Poverty

133.
The SSSDP addresses key areas of reform in social protection and labor markets. The
policy  conditions  of  the  SSSDP  are  pro-poor  and  contribute  to  overall  poverty  reduction  by
promoting  human  resource  development,  improved  governance,  and  pro-poor  growth  through
allowing  the  poor  to  compete  better  in  challenging  labor  markets.  Policy  reforms  related  to
improving  the  quality  and  coverage  of  social  welfare  benefits  and  allowances  will  have  a
substantial  impact  on  the  welfare  of  the  poor  by  increasing  the  proportion  of  poor  who  are
covered by the system.

134. Up  to  230,000  people  are  expected  to  benefit  from  the  social  assistance  and  welfare
policy  services  component  of  whom  160,000  currently  live  below  the  poverty  line.  The  main
beneficiaries are the most vulnerable among the elderly, PWD, pregnant and nursing mothers,
mothers with many dependent children and single-headed households.

135. Policy  reforms  related  to  the  labor  market  and  skills  training  will  enable  access  to
advisory and counseling services offered by EROs and quality employment-oriented education
and training to increased numbers of the unemployed who currently have no such opportunities.

The availability of such programs will be enhanced by enabling private sector participation in the
delivery  of  education  and  training  programs.  Up  to  260,000  unemployed  people,  of  whom
143,000 live below the poverty line, are likely to benefit from expanded access to employment
services.

136.
Improving  SSIGO’s  ability  to  enforce  compliance  of  social  insurance  payments  will
increase  levels  of  security  for  workers  close  to  the  poverty  line  by  ensuring  that  they  receive
benefit payments in the case of unemployment or occupational injuries or diseases. Clearing up
the sizable arrears of state budget organizations will reduce delays in providing social insurance
benefits, a major source of income for poor households. About 330,000 people will benefit from
this intervention, including 285,000 who live below the poverty line.

The  investment  project  is  directly  targeting  the  extreme  poor  and  vulnerable  groups.
137.
Social welfare service facilities will be improved, targeting, among others, PWD and elderly. To
target the extreme poor, community-based projects will be established to improve the quality of
life, protect the poorest of the poor, and raise levels of human development in selected areas.
About 10,000 poor people will directly benefit from these activities. Additionally, 9,750 very poor
unemployed  (of  whom  females  are  disproportionately  represented)  will  be  trained  to  increase
their income opportunities under the investment component.

B.

Risks and Safeguards

138. Political  Risks.  Although  the  Government  changed  frequently  in  the  late  1990s,
delaying  the  processing  of  the  SSSDP,  the  current  Government  is  stable  and  the  SSSDP’s
implementation  is  not  likely  to  be  disrupted.  Implementation  of  reforms,  which  will  change
criteria for entitlement to social welfare benefits, could prove controversial and may encounter
resistance.  Consequently,  effective  support  measures,  especially  for  employment  promotion,
need to be provided for people whose entitlement is removed. At the same time, the quality of
social welfare services must be improved to convince the public of the need for such reforms.
Reforms in social insurance must also be handled carefully to prevent loss of confidence in the
system.  To  mitigate  these  risks,  the  principal  safeguard  will  be  ensuring  maximum  popular
participation in designing and implementing the measures. To achieve this, the local parliaments
must  have  a  role  in  the  change,  and  public  education  campaigns  should  be  well  used  to  gain
support for policy reforms.

139.
Institutional Risks. A potential risk to effective implementation is the lack of institutional

upgrading of  skills and knowledge  of key staff, will, therefore, be crucial to the success of  the

POVERTY IMPACT ASSESSMENT

1.
Under the command economy before 1990, the social sectors in Mongolia received high
levels  of  investment  and  fiscal  support.  Access  to  employment  was  nearly  universally
guaranteed  and  there  was  no  recognized  unemployment.  Health  and  education  services  were
widespread  and  accessible  because  of  the  high  priority  the  Government  placed  on  human
development. The social security system was based on a combination of consumer subsidies,
universal  benefits  transferred  from  the  central  budget,  and  state  sector  wages.  All  sectors  of
society  were  covered  by  the  pension  systems  and  the  state  also  provided  a  comprehensive
range of social protection benefits to families, children, and groups designated as “vulnerable.”
About 40 percent of government expenditures were devoted to social development.a

Following transition, the Government made steps to change the social welfare  system
2.
from provision of universal access to targeted interventions. Additionally, expenditures allocated
to  social  security  remained  relatively  high,  16.5  percent  of  total  public  expenditures  in  1998.
Despite these efforts the present social welfare system, which covers retirement, disability and
survivor  pensions,  work  injury,  unemployment,  maternity  benefits,  health,  a  social  insurance
system, and a national poverty alleviation program have had limited impact on poverty.

A.       Poverty and Social Characteristics

3.
The  incidence  of  poverty  in  Mongolia  is  high;  about  36  percent  of  the  population  live
below the poverty line and about 20 percent live in extreme poverty.b The last official estimate of
poverty showed that poverty was disproportionately urban, with 57.2 percent of the poor resided
in urban areas and 42.8 percent residing in rural areas. However the weather-induced shock of
the severe storms in the winters of 1999 – 2000 and 2000-2001 and the intervening drought in
the summer of 2000 has had a deleterious impact on the rural population.

Growth in income poverty since 1990 has been accompanied by a concomitant decline
4.
in the ability to enjoy basic capabilities. Problems of malnutrition among children under five have
raised  concerns  about  food  security.  Previous  achievements  in  education  have  been  eroded.
Enrollment  in  grades  1  to  8  declined  from  near  universal  levels  (99  percent)  in  1990  to  82
percent  in  1997.  While  concerted  efforts  by  the  Government  resulted  in  an  increase  in
enrollment  rates  to  90  percent,  the  decline  in  the  intervening  years  however,  has  produced  a
large number of children whose capacities in the long term have been impaired by the years of
lost education.

The  official  rate  of  unemployment  is  6.5  percentc  (39,000  people)  but  actual  levels  are
5.
undeniably higher. Actual unemployment (after adjusting for those employed outside the formal
sector) ranges from 17 to 23 percent of the population. The provinces in particular have suffered
from massive layoffs of workers by private firms and the public service. Also, the incidence of
young  people  unable  to  work  is  increasing  with  severe  social  and  economic  consequences.
Loss  of  employment  is  the  most  prevalent  trigger  of  impoverishment  in  Mongolia.d  Nearly  58
percent of all unemployed are poor.

Gender

11.
During the transition to a new market economy, the economic and social independence
of the female half of the population has been severely undermined. Reduction in health and/or
social services results in women having to spend more time caring for the young, sick, and/or
elderly.

12. Women account for 52.2 percent of the unemployed.g Women were the first to be laid off
upon  closure  or  restructuring  of  processing,  and  trade  industries  that  traditionally  hired  many
women.  After  disintegration  of  Government-owned  agricultural  farms  and  privatization  of  their
livestock and machinery, more than 20,000 trained women lost their jobs.h Only 39.7 percent of
women receive any social benefits as compared to 60.4 percent of men.

13. 
According to the Law on Pensions and Benefits from the Social Insurance Fund (1995),
many women aged 36-55 who had 4 or more children are pushed into retirement. Because of
this law, women’s right to work, and choose their jobs is limited. Additionally, women aged 55
who  contributed  to  the  Pension  Fund  for  not  less  than  20  years  can  receive  pension  if  they
desire so; men must be 60. This forces women into earlier retirement than men.

14.
Specific attention needs to be paid to women’s unique problems and life patterns when
considering social welfare services and benefits, labor market policies, and strengthening of the
social insurance system. Labor market interventions must go beyond a purely traditional agenda
to  adequately  address  special  concerns  of  women,  such  as  a  higher  incidence  of  homework,
competing demands from other household responsibilities, and the particular needs surrounding
child  bearing.  Social  insurance  programs  need  to  be  designed  to  take  into  account  the  longer
lives of women, and the additional implications for women of the risk of loss of support due to
death, of abandonment by or divorce from a spouse, and the less stable earning patterns found
among women.

1.
Rationale.  At  present,  Mongolia  relies  on  an  inherited  system  of  institutional  social
welfare  services  for  vulnerable  groups.  The  system  is  not  cost  effective,  is  against  traditional
Mongolian regard for the family, and (most important) is not the best way to deal with members of
vulnerable  groups  in  need  of  assistance.  While  institutionalization  may  be  required  for  a  limited
number  of  people,  community-based  approaches  to  social  welfare  services  will  address  the
above  issues.  Although  such  approaches  have  been  implemented  in  Mongolia  in  a  limited
manner  they  are  comparatively  new.  They  also  require  adapting  to  the  specific  situation  in
Mongolia  today  and  people  will  need  time  to  adjust  to  them.  They  will  also  require  cooperation
between  local  government  and  civil  society  organizations.  To  gain  greater  understanding  of  the
possible interventions suitable to Mongolia, to demonstrate the effectiveness of such approaches,

delivery, a development facility for innovations in this area will be incorporated into the project.

A.

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE

1.
The  TA  is  designed  to  address  the  shortcomings  in  social  security  services  in  Mongolia
which arise from the absence of any comprehensive policy and planning framework for medium
and long-term reform and development and for coordination of internal and external resources for
the sector. With a lack of any such comprehensive approach at present the sector suffers from
major inefficiencies caused by short-term, ad hoc and often uncoordinated planning processes.

The TA is also designed to address the urgent need to mobilize additional resources for
2.
social  security.  Reflecting  their  communist  origins  in  Mongolia,  social  security  services  remain
very much the preserve of the Government, with relatively little participation of civil society or the
private  sector.  In  addition,  the  lack  of  effective  coordination  of  donor  activities  means  that  this
assistance does not always yield optimal results.

3.
There is, therefore, an urgent need for a sector-wide framework for policy and strategy –
which  has  broad  popular  support  -  to  better  guide  programs  of  support  and  to  ensure  that  they
are in accordance with domestic legislation, policies and priorities.

B.

Objectives

The TA for Strengthening Policy for Social Security Reform will assist the government in
4.
the development of a comprehensive Social Security Sector Master Plan comprising policies and
strategies  designed  to  establish  an  efficient  social  security  sector  appropriate  to  a  market-
oriented  economy.  The  TA  will  help  the  Government,  and  the  Ministry  of  Social  Welfare  and
Labor (MSWL) in particular, develop a comprehensive framework for the medium and long-term
development  of  the  social  security  sector.  It  will  also  render  support  for  mobilization  and
coordination of both internal and external resources for financing of the social security sector.
